channel.title: Arrays?
channel.description:
I am working with arrays right now and I am wondering if you can somehow set an integer's value equal to the amount of items inside of an array. Example:
If my array has five items (String[] array1 = { "item1", "item2", "item3", "item4", "item5" };) and set an integer like (int arrayContent;) equal to 'five' without doing it by hand.
Another question, is it possible to set an integer array equivilant to the amount of items in a String array. So, if my String array has five items, my integer array would have { 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 }?

item.title: Arrays?
item.dc:creator: @Javacisnotrecognized _^_
item.description:
@Javacisnotrecognized wrote:

Maybe you should look at System.arrayCopy and [url=http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.4.2/docs/api/java/lang/Object.html#clone()]Object.clone

Read full topic

item.title: Arrays?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

ArrayLists and LinkedLists each are better than the other in specific instances.

ArrayLists are faster when:

-you need random access (like list[5] list[9], because it iterates all the way up from 0 to the number you want each and every time you call it)
-you need to iterate backwards (for the same reason as above, it would iterate from 0 up to the last item, then 0 to the last number-1 each time you want an item)

LinkedLists are faster when:

-you mostly add on the end (just creates a new node and adds it, no resizing of arrays)
-adding on the front (same as above)

They should have about the same speed when:

-iterating forward
-getting the size() (of course)

(note arraylist allocates an array bigger than the amount of items it has in it, and when you add enough to make it resize, it doubles the capacity of the array, so it doesn’t really resize things that often at all.)

I probably left a few things out, basically if you aren’t sure one great thing about java is you can just use the List interface in your code, then go back and change one line later to switch between arraylist, linkedlist or any other kind of list.

Read full topic

item.title: Arrays?
item.dc:creator: @pplsuqbawlz pplsuqbawlz
item.description:
@pplsuqbawlz wrote:

The best definition of an array is a list.

The variable name is how one identifies said list.

Of course there are qualifiers for this list, they have to be of the same object type.

But this is only logical, one doesn’t make a list for the grocery store and include their lifely goals in it?

Unless of course they’re schizophrentic.

example:

List About PPLSUQBAWLZ:
-Programmer.
-Rs2 Cheating Pioneer.
-Funny name.
-Charming.

?-I would like to have sex with Monica Lewinsky because it'd be funny to say "I did not have sexual relations with that woman." in an "Arkansas" manner.

See? That’s schizophrenia. Of course I’m only joking, that woman is so not my type…

Read full topic

item.title: Arrays?
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

The better way is to use the short-hand for-loop if you’re working with arrays.

Here’s an example for a String array:

private String[] testArray = new String[10]; for(String str : testArray) { System.out.println(str); }

Doing it like that means you don’t have to reference the array index like shown above - it automatically assigns the current index’s value to the variable identifier declared in the for loop, which is str.

Read full topic

item.title: Arrays?
item.dc:creator: @White_Castle White Castle
item.description:
@White_Castle wrote:

String[] array1 = { "item1", "item2", "item3", "item4", "item5" }; int arrayContent = array1.length; int[] array2 = new int[arrayContent]; for(int i = 0; i < array2.length; i++) array2[i] = i;
